title.narrative: Transition for Inclusive Development in Eastern Congo (TRIDE)

description.narrative: • (Vulnerable) smallholder farmers and their families in rural villages, • Market actors, • (Local) Public authorities.

title.narrative: Outcome 1 : Access and security of land tenure by smallholders is improved to reduce land-related conflicts
% of HH with negotiated and secure medium/long-term access to land in concessions (by signing a minimum 5-year contract) disaggregated by gender (HH that enjoyed (more) secure tenure rights to land

description.narrative: A contract will be considered negotiated and secure when it is written and signed by both parties (the targeted concessionaires per project and a small-scale landless farmer per project) and the contract is for at least 5 years.

title.narrative: % of people who claim that conflicts over land (security/ access) have decreased in the last 12 months

description.narrative: Land conflicts refer to all aspects of contestation between people over land-related resources. They include territorial conflicts (e.g. between herders and farmers), agrarian conflicts (e.g. the struggle for possession of agricultural land), and conflicts over the use of mineral and forest resources. This indicator will be measured annually by asking the following question ("To what extent do you think land-related conflicts have decreased or not decreased during the last 12 months in your community? 1=They have increased a lot 2=They have increased 3=No change 4=They have decreased 5=They have decreased a lot)

title.narrative: % of small farmers who believe that the cost of renting land is affordable.

description.narrative: The cost of renting land is affordable when the farmer declares that the cost of renting land is affordable in relation to his purchasing power ( Do you think the price of renting land is affordable? YES/ NO).

title.narrative: Output 3.7 Farmers have better access to local, urban and regional markets
% of cooperatives well managed with an inclusive and functioning governance structure

description.narrative: A cooperative will be considered well managed and functional when it has at least five of the following elements of enterprise management: up-to-date accounts; management tools; a management committee and/or board of directors; organises at least quarterly management meetings and once a year a general assembly of members; has its own resources to ensure its activities (financial and operational autonomy); has a bank account for savings and investments with at least two signatories They will be considered inclusive when there are at least 30% of women

title.narrative: Output 3.5 Governance and functioning of cooperatives and support institutions for agro-pastoral value chains are improved
% of collective micro-enterprises (PIC) well managed with an inclusive and functioning governance structure

description.narrative: A micro/small/medium sized collective enterprise will be considered well managed and functional when it has at least five of the following business management elements: up-to-date accounting; management tools; a management committee and/or board of directors; organises at least quarterly management meetings and once a year a general assembly of members; has its own resources to ensure its activities (financial and operational autonomy); has a bank account for savings and investments with at least two signatories. They will be considered inclusive when there are at least 30% of women

title.narrative: Output 1.4 Appropriate solution mechanisms to address problems related to inter-community conflicts are implemented with the involvement of local, provincial and national authorities
# of social armnistices on intercommunity conflicts negotiated by the authorities, concluded and signed and respected by the parties

description.narrative: A social compromise on an inter-communal conflict refers to an agreement reached under the facilitation of a local authority by the conflicting parties at the end of mediation/peaceful conflict resolution. It must be written and signed by the conflicting parties with their addresses and contacts. To be considered, the compromise must be endorsed by the local or sectoral authority that countersigns it

title.narrative: Output 2.1 Good land stewardship and resilient farming systems are scaled up and promoted through the PIP approach
Number of hectares of farmland under >2 conservation practices within and out of concessions (BZ)

description.narrative: Conservation practices are grouped into 4 categories: Water management (irrigation or drainage), Soil fertility management (organic manure, crop rotation and mulching), Crop protection / Integrated plant disease and insect management. A land is under at least two conservation practices if and only if at least two practices belonging to two of the above categories are practiced.

title.narrative: Output 3.1 Security and patrimonial governance problems (corruption, harassment and barriers) hampering the development of value chains in the villages of intervention are addressed through a multi-stakeholder partnership approach
number of decisions taken by governments to mitigate insecurity and patrimonial governance problems in the intervention area (desegregated by government level: local, provincial and national)

description.narrative: Here, we are talking about measure taken by a member of the relevant authority at local, provincial and national level in order to reduce impact of insecurity problems/ issues in its entity.

title.narrative: # of operational security plans (PAS) implemented at Groupement level

description.narrative: The Operational Security Plan (OSP) is a document in which the security problems of a cluster are identified and solutions proposed. It is often drawn up or updated by the Local Community Safety Councils (LCSCs) or the grouping forum, as appropriate.

title.narrative: Output 2.6 Relevant IWRM infrastructures (irrigation schemes and others) are rehabilitated and built by the community with the support of the project.
# of hectares supplied by irrigation schemes rehabilitated or built

description.narrative: Number of hectares supplied by the constructed irrigation schemes and the number of additional hectares supplied by the rehabilitation of pre-existing irrigation schemes.

title.narrative: Output 1.1 Provincial land intervention strategies are developed and adopted by the provincial governments of North and South Kivu
# of SPIF (Stratégie Provinciale d’Intervention Foncière) developped

description.narrative: The SPIF is a set of tools for management, land use planning/agricultural subdivision and land use planning (agricultural cadastre as actor). A SPIF will be considered as implemented when it is converted into implementing measures and operational tools (management, land use planning/agricultural subdivision and land use plan (agricultural cadastre as actor))

title.narrative: Output 1.3 Agricultural and pastoral lands are identified and mapped in the target territories and agricultural cadastres are recognised and operational in both provinces
# of agricultural cadastre offices are established and operational

description.narrative: The cadastral office refers to the presence of a cadastral officer with an office dedicated to agricultural cadastral matters. It will be operational if this territorial agricultural cadastral office has not only the human means for its functioning but also the logistical means to perform its technical tasks continuously. For example, a facilitator, a table with management documents and some working equipment (theodolite, decameter, GPS, etc.).

title.narrative: Output 2.3 PIP farmers are structured around the G50 approach for more access to services, finances and markets
Volume of credits obtained by the household accompanied in the G50 approach

description.narrative: The volume of credit obtained by the households accompanied in the G50 approach represents the total amount received as credit by these households in a defined period of time

title.narrative: Output 2.5 Soil degradation in the intervention area is reduced and land restoration is being undertaken at a growing scale through collective actions.
Number of sub-watersheds restored

description.narrative: These are sub-watersheds where anti-erosion and anti-flooding activities are practiced

title.narrative: Output 3.6 Home-based or larger-scale processing facilities and innovative post-harvest activities are introduced and enhanced
Number of agricultural product processing enterprises from value chains supported by the project put in touch with cooperatives and/or sales market

description.narrative: This indicator is about agricultural product processing facilities from value chains actors supported by the project that are linked with cooperatives but also about the support of new processing units of the value chain actors linked to the coopperatives. Viable processing facilities are those with the necessary equipment for their operation and maintenance, adapted to the main agricultural or livestock products of the entities. They will be considered in contact with cooperatives or markets when there is a sales contract between the two parties

title.narrative: Output 1.2 Farmers who rent land on a short-term basis in concessions have medium/long-term (5 years minimum) access to the land.
# of smallholder farmers benefiting from land facilitated by the project through lease contracts ( desegregated by sex)

description.narrative: A smallholder farmer will be considered a beneficiary of the arable land made available by the project if he or she has a (written) arable land lease agreement with a concessionaire targeted by the project for any length of time.

title.narrative: # of hectares of land made available through lease contracts for smallholder farmers within those concessions

description.narrative: This indicator measures arable land owned by concessionaires but made accessible to small-scale producers by concessionaires on the basis of advocacy by the TRIDE project and through written contracts between the two parties (small-scale producers and concessionaires) regardless of the duration of the contract.

title.narrative: Output 3.8 State actors and support institutions have improved their services for a value chain-friendly business environment
# of decisions made by state actors to improve the business climate in the project areas
Outcome 3. Local economy is revitalized through inclusive development and profitable value chains and the market system (MSD)
# of jobs created for youth, women, men at farm level thanks to TRIDE actions

description.narrative: The jobs created refer to the number of casual jobs in the fields (facilitated by the project through rental contracts) in terms of labour for women, youth (children i.e. < 15 years old are not taken into account cfr No child labour) and men

title.narrative: # of jobs created for youth, women, men within targeted value chains actors supported by the project
Household poverty line in the intervention areas

description.narrative: The poverty line is the minimum income below which a person is considered poor.

title.narrative: increase monthly household income in target villages

description.narrative: Monthly income is the sum of monthly expenditures in a household for different consumption items (proxy for income)

title.narrative: Output 2.4 Local and provincial land use and sustainable watershed management plans are developed
% of households using at least 2 agro-ecological practices in their fields

description.narrative: Conservation practices are grouped into 4 categories: Water management (irrigation or drainage), Soil fertility management (organic manure, crop rotation and mulching), Crop protection / Integrated plant disease and insect management. A land is under at least two conservation practices if and only if at least two practices belonging to two of the above categories are practiced.

title.narrative: Conflict sensitivity indicator
% of community members who are optimistic about the future stability of their areas

description.narrative: Community members who are optimistic about the future stability of their areas are those who say they are optimistic or very optimistic about the future stability of their areas.

title.narrative: % of community members who report feeling safe in their daily activities

description.narrative: Community members who report feeling safe are those who report being safe or very safe in their daily activities. Daily activities refer mainly to activities in the field as well as other activities of a social nature such as going to the market, hospital, church, visiting relatives, school, work, etc.

title.narrative: Outcome 2. Integrated Water Resources Management is strengthened to promote resilient agricultural systems in North and South Kivu
Degree of integrated water resources management implementation (0-10)

description.narrative: The IWRM implementation level is a composite index based on the UNEP tool. IWRM is defined by the Global Water Partnership/Technical Advisory Committee as a process that promotes the coordinated development and management of water, land and related resources, with a view to maximising, in an equitable manner, the resulting economic and social well-being, without compromising the sustainability of vital ecosystems. at the national level Two rounds of reporting on the indicator have taken place to date, namely the 2017 round (baseline data). These reports are done on a 3-year interval. For this project, surveys will be conducted at the territorial and provincial level to establish the index

title.narrative: % of HH with increased food & nutritional situation from improved dietary intake (FSC)

description.narrative: The household will be considered as having a good FSC when its score is acceptable (?41)

title.narrative: % of small scale food producers whose livelihood became more resilient to shocks

description.narrative: A small-scale agricultural producer is said to be resilient when the household can meet an urgent and unforeseen expense such as illness requiring at least $100 without selling its productive assets.

title.narrative: Average increase in food production per household in Kcal

description.narrative: To get a complete understanding of food security in a region, it is not enough to look only at food consumption. Information on production is also needed. Grain equivalents allow evaluators and researchers to capture the production of the most important crops in a single unit of measurement, making it easier to set targets and compare

title.narrative: Output 2.7 Involvement of local, provincial and national authorities in IWRM and promotion of resilient agricultural systems is increased
# of decisions, policies taken by authorities to promote IWRM practices, resilient agricultural (desegregation: at local, provincial and national levels)

description.narrative: A policy decision is an administrative measure taken by an administrative authority to promote the agricultural sector (IWRM and agro-ecological practices) in its entity.

title.narrative: Output 3.2 Value chain actors improved their capacities and have better access to finance through formal institutions
Volume of credits obtained by the cooperatives accompanied in the value chains

description.narrative: The volume of credit obtained by the cooperatives accompanied in the value chains represents the total amount of credit received by the cooperatives within a defined period of time

title.narrative: % smallholders who accessed formal loans from a formal financial service in the last 12 months
Output 2.2 PIP households improve their knowledge of wise use of food
% of PIP households who know at least 3 good nutrition practices

description.narrative: 10 good nutritional practices are defined in Module 7 of the Nutritional Guidelines, namely: 1. Nutrition for pregnant and lactating women 2. Iron and iodine supplementation 3. Exclusive breastfeeding 4. Supplementary feeding 5. Supplementation in vitamin A 6. Deworming 7. Nutritional assessment/growth monitoring 8. Fruit and vegetable consumption 9. Eating and moving more 10. The 5 keys to safer eating

title.narrative: Output 3.3 Farmers (women, men and youth from different ethnic groups) have improved their production per hectare and income for the targeted value chains
Increase (in %) of agricultural production per hectare

description.narrative: The following agricultural products should be considered: Rutshuru: maize, soya and sorghum Nyiragogo: Potatoes Masisi: Potatoes Kalehe: Coffee and beans Uvira: Rice and maize. An increase in agricultural production is said to occur when the quantity produced p has increased from a quantity X to a quantity Y , Y being > X

title.narrative: Output 3.4 Organised groups of entrepreneurs (women, men and young people) are promoted in all PIP villages on the basis of the integrated collective plan (PIC)
Number of commercial contractual agreements negotiated and signed between cooperatives and market actors in the different value chains (suppliers, buyers)

description.narrative: Commercial contractual agreements refer to contracts negotiated and signed between cooperatives and market actors (input suppliers, wholesale or retail buyers, processing companies, storage companies, etc.).

title.narrative: Quantity (Kg) of target products in the value chain marketed in urban centers or out of the country by cooperatives (AGRITERRA) and other economic actors (ZOA) supported by the project (disaggregated by commodity)

description.narrative: Urban centres refer to markets or sales points in urban areas/city and/or abroad where cooperatives and other economic actors supported by the project sell or market their products. The sale of agricultural products in urban markets or out of the country can be direct (by the cooperative itself through its members or managers) or indirect (through some partner organisations or agricultural cooperatives).
